Do Right to Carry Laws deter crime ? 
 
 http://www.youdebate.com/DEBATES/gun_right_to_carry.HTM
Very simple question. YES They do. I am going to go dig up some stats.
A very big yes. When I carry, you can bet there will be no crime within a 20 ft radius of where I stand.

I say yes too!
 If I am carrying for protection, I myself, will have less chance of becoming the victum of crime.
Hmmmmm....let's see...if I were a criminal, would I be frightened by the thought of someone carrying a gun? YES!!!
Were are all the gun control people with there rebutles. Wow, seems so simple sometimes!:D
the gun-control XXXXXX are still waiting for more XXXXXXXX lies to be made up since they have no truths to back up their piece of XXXX XXXXX XXX ideas.

Originally posted by sarablaze 
 Were are all the gun control people with there rebutles. Wow, seems so simple sometimes!:D 
 
 
 I believe they got XXXXXX at all the conservates on this board. So they went and joined a commie discussion board where they feel more welcome and can send congrats to each other for being smarter than regular people.

Can you back up your opinions with facts? Let's look at some facts. States that have restrictive concealed weapons laws or don't allow people to carry concealed handguns at all experienced a 30% decrease in crime. States that allow a lot of people to carry concealed handguns only experienced a 15% reduction in crime.
 
 http://www.bradycampaign.org/facts/research/conctruth.asp
 
 Allowing less people to carry concealed handguns means a greater reduction in crime.

Originally posted by voiceofreason 
 Can you back up your opinions with facts? Let's look at some facts. States that have restrictive concealed weapons laws or don't allow people to carry concealed handguns at all experienced a 30% decrease in crime. States that allow a lot of people to carry concealed handguns only experienced a 15% reduction in crime.
 
 http://www.bradycampaign.org/facts/research/conctruth.asp
 
 Allowing less people to carry concealed handguns means a greater reduction in crime. 
 
 
 I don't care about what happens on the news or a neighborhood across town. I am concerned about the statistics within a 15 ft. of me when I walk out to the car at night.
 
 Crime statistics are based on a lottery. Winning the crime lottery at night in a parking lot is one lottery I don't want to win.

In effect what you argue is I should give up my personal safety for the common good of my community.
 
 No thanks. I don't think the community will be there to help me when a mugger jumps me and beats me to take my wallet.

Well since we are supposed to take a biased study just as is here is one I conducted. 
 I went to the Brady site and looked at the grades states got and for what reason the got them
 
 Maryland: had an A- becuase the limit CCW and has a one gun per month law
 
 Montana: had an F allows Concealed Weapons to be carried and it does not regulate the sale of private firearms
 
 Maryland violent crime: 786.6 per 100,000
 Montana violent crime: 240.6 per 100,000
 
 I dont know about you but I would feel safer in Montana. Now I would like to open the forum for excuses that the anti gun club has for these numbers and the ones I presented on the U.K. which no one has disputed me yet on that thread.
Heck, guess i'll move to Montana if I can't fix CT. :D
I like you Patriot you like to listen to reason.

LOL
 
 Are there any states better than Montana? I think AZ will let you carry unconceled w/o a permit. Any other states do that?
Maybe that's because Montana has a sparse population with no major cities.

Why dont you go get me some stats then Crim. Typically states with laxed CCW laws already had a lower crime rate so there was not much room for a drop in crime thus they had a drop not as much as the onces with strict CCW laws. 
 
 This is a prime example of how the Brady Center uses facts in a distorted way, in order to lie to the rest of us. Hence the Brady Center is composed of liars. 
 Why do you think they did not include crime stats in their study?
 
 And Point being, states with laxed CCW have lower violent crime rates than the ones that have strict or no CCW.

Crim is exactly right. It is not surprising that Maryland has higher crime rate. Urban areas tend to have higher crime rates than rural areas. The Brady statistics say that New York experienced a 43% drop in violent crime and California had a 37% drop in the violent crime rate. Gun-control leads to a drop in the crime rate.

You are really going to hurt for that statement.
 
 WHERE ARE YOUR STATS BACKING THAT UP?!?!?! 
 Why dont you have any, because there are NONE that say that, there are no UN BAISED stats that say that gun control lowers crime! So no facts at all back up your absurd claim.
 What are the crime rates in NY and Cal. exactly?
 
 In 1997 they banned guns in the U.K. and crime has gone up 47% I will cite a source WHICH YOU HAVE FAILED TO DO.
 
 http://www.crimereduction.gov.uk/statistics21.htm
 
 Go to page 60 of the report and tell me what it says crime did after they banned guns.
 Enjoy!

I'll vouch for Arizona. I can carry a pistol on my hip or a rifle on a sling down the street, with no permit. You only need a permit if you want to carry concealed. The great thing about the permit is I can purchase any firearm over the counter that day and go home with it. 
 
 Some wierd parts of the law: in a car the gun in a glovebox is concealed. You have to put it on the front seat, if you don't have a permit. The permit also applies to knives. It is a concealed weapons permit, not a concealed gun permit.

A very horrific day in NY. As of yet I know nothing of the shooter. I bet that the shooter was not a school teacher, a preacher, or Mormon kids just out for a good time. This is should not happen in NY, guns on the street are banned in NY.

Makes ya wonder, doesn't it kelvin? NYC has got to have the most effective gun control in the US.

 JFriday:
 
 In fairness, no one, pro or ant-gun can ever use UK stats to support thier argument again. Back in Jan '03 the UK government finally came clean and announced that they had been seriously fu**ing with crime statistics.
 
 You can make the argument that the UK state had something to hide with guncontrol and you would probably be right. Reliable information from UK ministries should now be accepted as less than credible.
As far as an anti-gun statistic showing the benefits of gun bans, I have never seen one here. Maybe because they don't exist.

Kelvin, in responce to your post.
 
 That is why I do not use their crime stats, just the number of offences not the number of crime. The source I cited is consistent with the International Crime Victims survey. If you were to go to the Scottland yard website you would see that the numbers are lower, that is what they like to report, the number of crimes prosocuted. The Home Office website contains the number of offences committed. That is why I cited that one. And it was Scottland yard officials who said that they "may" have "accidently" messed up the numbers. Of course I would not use those as they are strongly inncorrect.

The UK only has 1.3 gun homicides per million. Germany only has 2.1 gun homicides per million. France only has 5.5 gun homicides per million. Australia only has 5.6 gun homicides per million. Canada only has 6.0 gun homicides per million. 
 
 The US has 62.4 gun homicides per million!
 
 http://www.handgunfree.org/HFAMain/research/abroad/comparison.htm

The UK has only 1.3 gun homicides per million. I doubt that. I agree the rate for the UK is far less. But I seriously doubt that number. If we are to use the UK as an example to follow, you have to ask yourself, then is that the kind of society we want:
 
 http://www.untitleddocument.co.uk/Issue4/usukviolent.html
 
 
 They are not any safer.

Originally posted by voiceofreason 
 The UK only has 1.3 gun homicides per million. Germany only has 2.1 gun homicides per million. France only has 5.5 gun homicides per million. Australia only has 5.6 gun homicides per million. Canada only has 6.0 gun homicides per million. 
 
 The US has 62.4 gun homicides per million!
 
 http://www.handgunfree.org/HFAMain/research/abroad/comparison.htm 
 
 
 I have saw your website. How do you explain Finland. I also don't belive the Swiss crime stat. Every male of military service has ammo and an assault rifle in his closet. The Swiss man may not own the rifle, but they all have one. Your website is manufacturing statistics.
 
 There can be no reliable numbers trusted from the UK. The state has already admitted to "jimmy-ing" the numbers in Jan '03. When your website relys on those shady numbers, then can you believe the others.
 
 Or do you trust Dan Rather.

Frankly, I don't care if the US statistics were twice as high as they are. The countries you listed, voiceofreason, are, in my opinion, some of the most oppresive nations in existance. Not the most oppressive by far, but they certainly aren't free, even if they are safer. 
 
 
 I'D RATHER BE FREE THAN SAFE. There is a choice. You cannot have both, because a government big enough to give you both is big enough to take both away, to paraphrase Debater's signature quote.

Reading this thread I am horrified by anti-gunners logic. Anti-gunners are trying to change public policy and laws based on weak evidence and just plain wrong logic. To bad we lost the postings on 3/8 regarding the Department of Justice study on assault weapons. Forming public policy and laws based on uncertainty and hookuspokus is just plain dumb.
 
 I am open to anti-gunners websites and and studies. At the very least they point to something that is broken in our society and needs fixing. From what I have seen, I am not convinced the problem is with firearm ownership.

Voice of Reason
 
 Perhaps an UNBAISED site would help your arugments. Did you know that according to the International Crime Victims Survey that the U.S. is no longer in the top 10 for the worlds leading crime rates except for burglary(defined as illeagle entry and theft of possesions in a home or buisness with no occupants present) and in burglary we are number 8.
 
 www.unicri.it/icvs/statistics/index_stats.htm
 
 Look under the industrialized nations and compare our crime stats with those of the countries you mentioned.
Look for my reply in the regular "Gun Control" thread

Originally posted by Patriot 
 Frankly, I don't care if the US statistics were twice as high as they are. The countries you listed, voiceofreason, are, in my opinion, some of the most oppresive nations in existance. Not the most oppressive by far, but they certainly aren't free, even if they are safer. 
 
 I'D RATHER BE FREE THAN SAFE. There is a choice. You cannot have both, because a government big enough to give you both is big enough to take both away, to paraphrase Debater's signature quote. 
 
 
 In the Declaration of Independence, Thomas Jefferson identifies the right to life as a fundamental freedom. If more gun-control saves lives then more gun-control means more freedom. Aren't you pro-gunners interested in freedom?
Gun control wont save lives, Voice of Reason, I have already demonstrated this.
concur w/ JFriday. we are interested in freedom which is why we are pro-gun.

Originally posted by voiceofreason 
 In the Declaration of Independence, Thomas Jefferson identifies the right to life as a fundamental freedom. If more gun-control saves lives then more gun-control means more freedom. Aren't you pro-gunners interested in freedom? 
 
 
 I am interested in my life and freedom. I am not responsible for yours or anyone else I don't know. You fail to address how do you protect me when you take my gun? That is a pretty crappy trade. Your increase in personal protection and the decrease of mine? No thank you.

Originally posted by kelvin90701 
 I am interested in my life and freedom. I am not responsible for yours or anyone else I don't know. You fail to address how do you protect me when you take my gun? That is a pretty crappy trade. Your increase in personal protection and the decrease of mine? No thank you. 
 
 
 I can't believe this. You say, "That is a pretty crappy trade. Your increase in personal protection and the decrease of mine?" So you admit that I would be safer if you didn't have a gun. I am not a criminal. So you're admitting that you and your guns endanger innocent lives. That's what you said. That's a very good reason to take away your guns.

How do your propose to do that? Have the police knock down my door and take them? 
 
 Very damn noble of you to make me sacrifice for your ideas.

Originally posted by kelvin90701 
 How do your propose to do that? Have the police knock down my door and take them? 
 
 Very damn noble of you to make me sacrifice for your ideas. 
 I am making you sacrifice for my own freedom and the freedom of other innocent people. Don't you believe in freedom? I say pass a law that requires you to serve a 5 year prison sentence if you get caught with a gun. That'll certainly deter you from owning a gun.

The WW2 German Ace who shot down more than 300 planes was being award a medal by Hitler. Before the presentation, Hartmann was asked to leave his pistol outside. His response, "If the Fuhrer doesn't turst me, I don't want his medal."
 
 You don't trust me, I don't want your protection.
 
 Your personal safety is your own responsibility. There is no community responsibility owed to you.

Why would I trust you? You yourself admitted that other people would be safer if you did not have a gun.
 
 
Your personal safety is your own responsibility. There is no community responsibility owed to you.
 Then why do the police and the FBI exist? How about neighborhood watch programs? According to your logic these programs and organizations should all be abolished. Safety is a personal as well as a community responsibility.

Not your personal saftey. You can not sue the police for not responding fast enough. You can not sue the police for failure to protect you. The police and FBI are there to clean up the mess after a murder, not prevent one.
 
 If you do not take ANY (martial arts, mace, a cell phone, what ever you like) means to protect yourself, then no one is protecting you.
 
 Sleep well tonight.

It's still a shared responsibility. The police can be held responsible for your public safety if they fail do their part. In the Jeffery Dahmer case, police officers were suspended because they failed to save a young Laotian boy from Dahmer after receiving a 911 call. A special commission is also investigating the conduct of police in the Elizabeth Smart case.

Do you realize as a civilian you are liable for taking law enforcement duties in your own hands? Not only does the law discourage me from sharing the responsibility of protecting other people, but I am held to a higher standard of civil suit; and have none of the civil suit protection the police enjoy.
 
 Here in Arizona someone who tried to share the responsibility went to prison. A good samaritian saw a woman being attacked on a dark street by a man with a knife. He rushed to help the woman, took the knife and stabbed the man. The man was an undercover cop, the woman a hooker attacking the cop. The good samaritain went to jail.
 
 So VOR, go out and help your community and share the responsibility. I am sure you will do a better job.

I do intend to help my community and share the responsibility through non-violent means. I'm not going to go around stabbing and shooting people who I think are criminals. That's not the way to do it. The way to do it is to pass stricter gun-control laws.
 
 I'm not going to stand by idly and watch as thousands of people are killed each year with guns in the US. You might be content to bury your head in the sand and pretend everything is rosy, but I believe in getting involved and trying to make a difference. It's called being a concerned citizen.

Originally posted by voiceofreason 
 I do intend to help my community and share the responsibility through non-violent means. I'm not going to go around stabbing and shooting people who I think are criminals. That's not the way to do it. The way to do it is to pass stricter gun-control laws.
 
 I'm not going to stand by idly and watch as thousands of people are killed each year with guns in the US. You might be content to bury your head in the sand and pretend everything is rosy, but I believe in getting involved and trying to make a difference. It's called being a concerned citizen. 
 
 
 What is your non-violent way of stopping a felon with a knife? A felon who at 30 has spent 10 years in prison and was raped by other prisoners?
 
 I suspect you will do what most New Yorkers will do when they witness a crime: NOT GET INVOLVED!
 
 I will stop carrying a pistol when life is rosy. What else do you do to protect yourself besides being concerned?

After a period of time, the Swiss Army gives away guns.
 
 "Today, enlisted men are issued M57 automatic assault rifles and officers are given pistol, Each reservist is issued 24 rounds of ammunition in sealed packs for emergency use. (Contrary to Handgun Control's claim that "all ammunition must be accounted for," the emergency ammunition is the only ammo that requires accounting.)
 
 After discharge from service, the man is given a bolt rifle free from registration or obligation. Starting in the 1994, the government will give ex-reservists assault rifles. Officers carry pistols rather than rifles and are given their pistols the end of their service.
 
 When the government adopts a new infantry rifle, it sells the old ones to the public. "
 
 http://pages.prodigy.net/vanhooser/the_swiss_and_their_guns.htm

I donate money to gun-control groups. That's one way of getting involved. Dialing 911 is another way of getting involved. The incident you refer to in New York refers to nobody bothering to call the police when they witnessed a crime.
 
 You contradict yourself. First, you warn me of the dangers of using violent means to stop a crime. You told me the story of a well-intentioned person stabbing an undercover cop. Now you're saying that you yourself would carry a pistol. So you would be willing to use violent means to stop a crime. At least try to be consistent and don't change your story every 5 minutes so that you can win the argument.

I feel sorry that you don't get it. The law does not what you to get involved. The law will actually try to punish you if you try to help.
 
 Your only option is not to rely on help from other people, not to expect help from the police, your only option is to protect yourself.

Originally posted by voiceofreason 
 The incident you refer to in New York refers to nobody bothering to call the police when they witnessed a crime.
 
 
 
 I don't believe that the individual in this case should have been held liable. It was an honest mistake, and the cop should have yelled, "Hey, I'm a cop!" 
 
 Anyway, voiceofreason, do you really think that calling 911, watching someone die, and then being a really good witness for the police is a better outcome than actually having the nerve to stand up and protect another member of society? I'm not espousing heroics here. Only fools want to be heros, because 9 of 10 who try to be heros die in the process and never make that kind of status, but I feel that we have a responsibility to our fellow man to help on another. Donate to charity, volunteer for the girls and boy's club, and come to someones aid when they're in harm's way. The way I was raised, I see nothing heroic about coming to the aid of one who is being attacked, even if it means taking the life of the attacker. To run away, even if to call 911, is the route of one who ignores their responsibility to society.

Lets do a survey, if you are in a resturant and a guy comes in shooting, would you rather
 
 A) be sitting with someone who is going to call 911 and then try to pass tougher gun control laws
 
 B) or someone who is going to shoot the guy then call 911
 
 even simpler, would you rather have Kelvin or VOR in the resturant with your when the guy comes in shooting.
Kelvin, if i can't have a gun myself. emoticon_smile
A restaurant? How about church? Yes people have been killed in church. Yes I do pack heat in church. These is no safe or holly place for murderers.

I would definitly want kelvin by my side, and me and him could destroy any threat. Voice of Reason, why do you put so much faith in other people to protect you? Everybodies first instinct is to protect themselves, and nobody cares about you and the ones you love as much as yourself, so who better to protect you then you. 
 
 911 does not work, if someone breaks into your house with the intent to harm by the time you get done with 911 your kids are molested and kilt, your wifes been raped and you are breathing through your neck. beutiful thought isnt it.
That might happen, just not at my house, I go for a gun before I go for a phone, three steps, Equip, Identify, Kill, then go and call the police

To add to your list. Say nothing to the police other than any personal information that they need to process you. Then call a lawyer. Even if you are 100% justified, but assured the full extent of the law will come after you. Even if you are found innocent, you will have to pay to prove it.
I know, thanks to people like VOR we have laws in this country that punish the innocent more than the guilty, good job yall.

Allowing less people to carry concealed handguns means a greater reduction in crime.

 Bullsh^t. Permit holders are hundreds of times less likely to commit crimes than YOU, statistically speaking.

I do intend to help my community and share the responsibility through non-violent means.

 
 Non-violence is a non-answer.
 
 
I'm not going to go around stabbing and shooting people who I think are criminals. That's not the way to do it.

 
 Even when they're trying to stab or shoot you?
 
 
The way to do it is to pass stricter gun-control laws.

 
 And what're you going to do when a criminal says "F**k you and your gun control, it's not gonna keep me from getting a gun if I want one"?
 
 
You might be content to bury your head in the sand and pretend everything is rosy, but I believe in getting involved and trying to make a difference. It's called being a concerned citizen.

 
 yeah, and that's why most of us go through the paperwork to be able to legally carry guns. It's called being a concerned citizen.
Exactly. And understanding THE REAL WORLD as opposed to allowing your opinion to get spoonfed to you via the establishment media. THAT is being a truly concerned citizen.
